docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate Finance Committee voted Thursday to soften the impact of financial penalties that would be imposed on people who did not obtain insurance under sweeping health care legislation. Members of the committee changed the bill to exempt an estimated two million people who would face financial burdens in buying even the cheapest insurance available. Lawmakers delayed and reduced the penalties for others.

headline.main: Panel Easing Penalties for Those Without Insurance

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee votes to soften impact of financial penalties that would be imposed on people who do not obtain health insurance under sweeping health care legislation; changes would exempt roughly two million people who would face financial burdens in buying even cheapest insurance available; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The move would help people facing financial burdens in buying even the cheapest insurance available.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and JACKIE CALMES

docs.lead_paragraph: Spoiler alert: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the House minority leader, John A. Boehner, disagree on the popularity of the public option. The two leaders debated the issue Thursday via their weekly news conferences. Mr. Boehner, an Ohio Republican, said he had yet to talk to anyone -- besides some in Washington -- who backed a government-run insurance option.

headline.main: BY POPULAR DEMAND $(MDASH$) OR NOT; Vox Populi in Dispute

docs.abstract: Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Republican House Minority Leader John Boehner use their weekly news conferences to debate issue of public option in health care legislation; Pelosi says there is still overwhelming popular backing for public option; Boehner says he has yet to encounter anyone, outside of some Washington insiders, who supports government-run insurance option (S)
docs.snippet: Spoiler alert: The House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and the House minority leader, John A. Boehner, disagree on the popularity of the public option.     The two leaders debated the issue Thursday via their weekly news conferences. Mr. Boehner, an Ohio...

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House has often held out the Mayo Clinic as a model for health care. But Dr. Denis A. Cortese, above, the clinic's chief executive, says he is disgusted with the way Washington is approaching an overhaul of the nation's health care system. ''Look at all the time we're wasting,'' Dr. Cortese said Thursday in an interview, critiquing the Congressional debate. ''It's pretty heartbreaking to watch.''
docs.abstract: Dr Denis A Cortese, chief executive of Mayo Clinic, says he is disgusted with way in which Congress is approaching health care overhaul; says Congress has proven itself unable to withstand political pressure of lobbyists; White House has often invoked Mayo Clinic as model for health care; photo (S)
docs.snippet: The White House has often held out the Mayo Clinic as a model for health care. But Dr. Denis A. Cortese, above, the clinic's chief executive, says  he is  disgusted with the way Washington is  approaching an overhaul of the nation's health care...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, the only Republican on the Senate Finance Committee who has expressed any willingness to support the health care legislation, may be the most closely watched figure in the committee's debating sessions. As Thursday afternoon's proceedings wore on, Ms. Snowe got up to leave the dais -- senators frequently walk in and out -- and apparently tripped and fell. Aides helped gather her papers, and she quickly left the hearing room. A spokesman for Ms. Snowe said she was just fine.
docs.abstract: Spokeman for Sen Olympic Snowe says she is fine after tripping and falling while leaving Senate dais; Snowe is only Republican on Senate Finance Committee who has expressed willingnesss to support pending health care legislation (S)
docs.snippet: Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, the only Republican on the Senate Finance Committee who has expressed any willingness to support the health care legislation, may be the most closely watched figure in the committee's debating sessions.      As...

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and JACKIE CALMES

docs.lead_paragraph: China celebrates 60 years of Communist Party rule this week. But devotion to a socialist ideology seems to have been replaced by pride in rising standards of living and the ability to go shopping, at least in the glittering precincts of Shanghai and Beijing. The Chinese government is expanding subsidies for consumer spending on home appliances. Retail sales during the eight-day national holiday are expected to soar, and 560 million people are expected to travel in China during this holiday week.

headline.main: China's Next Stage: Spreading the Wealth

docs.abstract: Can China, 30 years after its opening to the West, become a consumer society?
docs.snippet: Can China, 30 years after its opening to the West, become a consumer society?

docs.lead_paragraph: A Democratic amendment intended to reduce Americans' exposure to potential fines for not having health insurance, as proposed in an emerging Senate health care bill, seemed on the verge of passage in the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday.

headline.main: When Senator Snowe Speaks, Democrats Pay Attention

docs.abstract: A Democratic amendment withdrawn demonstrates the power of Republican Senator Snowe.
docs.snippet: A Democratic amendment withdrawn demonstrates the power of Republican Senator Snowe.

docs.lead_paragraph: As everyone knows by now, Sarah Palin's upcoming memoir has already shot up to the No. 1 position on both Amazon.com and BarnesandNoble.com. The book, completed in about four months, is co-written by Lynn Vincent, whose background is being mined for details about the collaboration.

headline.main: Blogtalk: Palin, Death and the Olympics

docs.abstract: Speculation continues about Sarah Palin's coming memoir, while lawmakers continue haggling over apologies from the House floor.

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House has often held out the Mayo Clinic as a model for health care. But Dr. Denis A. Cortese, the clinic's chief executive, says he is disgusted with the current machinations in Washington over how to overhaul the nation's health care system.

headline.main: Mayo Clinic's Chief Finds Health Care Debate 'Heartbreaking'

docs.abstract: The Mayo Clinic's chief executive says he has better ideas for overhauling health care than the "heart breaking" process in Congress.
docs.snippet: The Mayo Clinic's chief executive says he has better ideas for overhauling health care than the "heart breaking" process in Congress.
